articles.title: üåü¬†The 2023 JavaScript Rising Stars
articles.description: At the start of each year, Michael rounds up the projects that gained the most popularity on GitHub in the prior year. Rocketing to #1 is the shadcn/ui suite of React components, but there are a lot of fresh entries. Bun and Next.js stay on the list, while htmx and Drizzle ORM make their first appearances in the top ten.
articles.author: Michael Rambeau et al.

articles.title: 10 Interview Questions Every JS Developer Should Know in 2024
articles.description: I‚Äôd usually shy away from a list-based post on Medium, but this is a good exception. As a rare example of a top-notch developer who's also involved in hiring other developers, Eric provides useful advice.
articles.author: Eric Elliott

articles.title: Vue 3.4 Released
articles.description: Vue 2 went ‚Äòend of life‚Äô last week, but never fear, we got a new version of Vue 3 to make up for it, complete with a rewritten, faster template parser, and a more efficient reactivity system. If you prefer a screencast tour, ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Erik Hanchett has one for you.
articles.author: Evan You

articles.title: Let's Bring Back JavaScript's with Statement..?
articles.description: Famously roasted in JavaScript: The Good Parts before its deprecation, with isn‚Äôt a popular language feature at all, so Alex's appeal here is partly tongue in cheek. Nonetheless, with has some potentially interesting uses in modern JavaScript.
articles.author: Alex MacArthur

articles.title: Making Sense of 'Senseless' JavaScript Features
articles.description: We‚Äôve tackled with (above), now Juan Diego Rodriguez looks at several other seemingly ‚Äúabsurd‚Äù JS eccentricities, explains how they came into existence, and tries to help you avoid the problems they cause.
articles.author: Juan Diego Rodriguez

articles.title: A Look at 2023's New Array Methods
articles.description: A look at toReversed(), toSplice(), toSorted(), and with() (no, not that with.. üòÜ)
articles.author: Chris Ferdinandi

articles.title: What the Heck is a Homomorphic Mapped Type?
articles.description: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs try to understand what the TypeScript guys mean when they talk about homomorphic mapped types.‚Äù
articles.author: Andrea Simone Costa

articles.title: React Server Components: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly
articles.description: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd argue that adding server capabilities to React is much less important than fixing its many existing issues.‚Äù
articles.author: Mayank

articles.title: Introduction to HTMX
articles.description: htmx is an interesting library for imbuing your HTML with dynamic functionality in a lightweight, dependency-free way.
articles.author: Refine

articles.title: üî•¬†Simulating Fluids, Fire, and Smoke in Real-Time
articles.description: Only tangentially JavaScript related, but a fantastic article nonetheless.
articles.author: Andrew Chan

articles.title: React Aria 1.0: 40+ Accessible Components, Your Way
articles.description: Anyone who follows Devon Govett (also of Parcel fame) on social media will know just how much he's put into this suite of components, and v1.0 is now here. If you‚Äôre building your own components and want to get accessibility right, this is for you. Devon explains a little more here.
articles.author: Adobe

articles.title: üìÜ ¬†Schedule-X: A Material Design Calendar and Date Picker
articles.description: Available in the form of React, Vue or plain JS components. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Tom √ñsterlund

articles.title: quick-lint-js 3.0: Tool to Find JavaScript Bugs As You Code
articles.description: We first linked this two years ago when it hit 1.0. It‚Äôs an interesting alternative to tools like ESLint and aims to give you instant feedback while coding. v3.0 introduces TypeScript support.
articles.author: Matthew Glazar

articles.title: Plotteus: A JavaScript Library for Data Storytelling
articles.description: Looks to be a powerful solution not just for creating static visualizations (graphs, plots, etc.) but interactive ones that visualize data changes via scrolling, UI controls, or other user interactions.
articles.author: Bartosz Prusinowski

articles.title: LIPS: A Scheme-Style Lisp in JavaScript
articles.description: A Lisp interpreter written in JavaScript that also has good integration with JavaScript both in the browser or atop Node.js.
articles.author: Jakub T. Jankiewicz

articles.description: Oracle is introducing JavaScript support in MySQL.
Some 2024 predictions from JS framework maintainers.

While I was still busy eating turkey, someone created an 'everything' npm package (complete with an 80MB package.json) that turned every public package into a dependency, preventing any of them from being unpublished. Unsurprisingly, this resulted in much drama. üòÖ
Minko Gechev walks through the results of the Angular Developer Survey 2023.
A look at both the current and future state of Storybook in 2024.
Dependency Cruiser 16.0 ‚Äì Validate and visualize dependencies.
VueFire ‚Äì A first-class Vue + Firebase experience.
Effection 3.0 ‚Äì Structured concurrency and effects.
Parcel 2.11 ‚Äì The zero config build tool.
Node.js v21.5.0 (Current)

articles.title: 01:¬†Six CSS Snippets Every Front-End Developer Should Know in 2023
articles.description: This look at a half-dozen toolbelt worthy, powerful, and broadly cross-compatible CSS techniques (including logical properties and container queries) proved very popular, and was the top link shared in Frontend Focus last year. Everything remains relevant in 2024 too, of course! üòè
articles.author: Adam Argyle

articles.title: 02:¬†A Deep Dive Into SVG Path Commands
articles.description: A very well presented, interactive guide to understanding SVG paths and path commands ‚Äî it covers cursors, lines, b√©zier curves, and more, and remains a bookmark-worthy resource.
articles.author: Nanda Syahrasyad

articles.title: 03:¬†If Web Components Are So Great, Why Am I Not Using Them?
articles.description: There was plenty of renewed chatter and attention on Web Components in the latter half of 2023, kicked off in part by Dave's analysis on the 'marketing problem' that this relatively slowly-adopted technology may have.
articles.author: Dave Rupert

articles.title: 04:¬†‚ñ∂Ô∏è 21 Awesome Web Features You‚Äôre Not Using Yet
articles.description: An eight-minute video that's closing in on nearly a million views now. It runs through some of the then-new features on the web platform, and remains a solid high-level, informative run through.
articles.author: Fireship

articles.title: 05:¬†A Blog Post with Every HTML Element
articles.description: A mammoth effort here ‚Äî it's a bold attempt to squeeze every single valid HTML element (along with some former elements like <marquee> and <blink>) into a single place.
articles.author: Patrick Weaver

articles.title: 06:¬†Ten Weird HTML Hacks That Shaped the Internet
articles.description: A superb, curious history lesson here looking back at old table hacks, CSS kludges, and various quirky coding strategies that helped web developers get things looking good before we had the modern tools at our disposal now.
articles.author: Ernie Smith

articles.title: 07:¬†The Top Front-End Tools of 2022
articles.description: It might feel a bit dated to share a 2022 round-up in 2024, but this collection of handy frontend tools remains relevant nonetheless with plenty of tools to help speed up your workflow.
articles.author: Louis Lazaris

articles.title: 08:¬†The Truth About CSS Selector Performance
articles.description: It's true. Certain CSS selectors are faster than others. This article explains, outlining the ones that are important to keep an eye on for performance.
articles.author: Patrick Brosset

articles.title: 09:¬†An Interactive Guide to CSS Grid
articles.description: An excellent primer from Josh on all things CSS Grid, sharing a mental model we can adopt in order to best understand how CSS Grid works and how we can use it effectively.
articles.author: Josh Comeau

articles.title: 10:¬†The 'End' of Front-End Development
articles.description: Another from Josh, this time addressing the rise of AI language models and how they may impact programming. Josh noted he was ‚Äúmuch more optimistic about what these AI advancements mean for the future of software development‚Äù.
articles.author: Josh W. Comeau
